subject: Re: [junit] Priority of Assertion?
msgSnippet: Yes closures would be nice... sigh :) if you can t change your language, change your language I guess :) On Mon, Jan 5, 2009 at 8:21 PM, Charlie Poole ... --
messageBody:
Yes closures would be nice... sigh :)

if you can't change your language, change your language I guess :)


On Mon, Jan 5, 2009 at 8:21 PM, Charlie Poole
<charlie@...> wrote:
> Hi Joakim,
>
>> In rMock we used the following contruct:
>>
>> public void testSomething() {
>> <code that we don't expect to throw an exception>
>> expectThatExceptionThrown(isInstanceOf(SomeException.class));
>> <code that we expect to throw an exception> }
>>
>> I think that idea is what Charlies assertThrows suggestion
>> hinted towards.
>
> In NUnit, I wrote it as
> Assert.Throws( typeof(SomeException) ), <delegate> );
> where <delegate> can be a named delegate, the name of
> a method or an anonymous delegate depending on the
> version of .NET you are using.
>
> Putting it in a single statement avoids the global issues
> that David writes about, but the approach does require
> something like a closure - a .NET delegate being basically
> a weak form of closure.
>
> Charlie
>
>> While this freedom can be abused it allows to precisely
>> pinpoint what should throw an exception. Also, you could do
>> all kind of hamcrest checks on the exception instance that is
>> not possible to do with annotations. The underlying
>> implementation in the rMock-case is that
>> expectThatExceptionThrows primes the framework with an
>> expection that any exception is checked against before the
>> exception is rethrown as an error (if the check passes the
>> Exception is expected and not rethrown).
>>
>> Jusr my 5 cents :)
>>
>>
>> On Wed, Dec 31, 2008 at 4:43 AM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>>
>> > Ilja,
>> >
>> > Thanks for thinking this through.
>> >
>> >
>> > > In my view, the behavior is in fact an artifact of an
>> implementation
>> > > detail - namely that asserts indicate failures by throwing an
>> > > exception.
>> >
>> > I don't know that I can get behind this. This test is
>> always going to pass:
>> >
>> > @Test public void avoidThePainfulTruth() { try {
>> assertTrue(false); }
>> > catch (Exception e) { } }
>> >
>> > I can't think of a better way than exceptions to implement
>> assertions,
>> > and I can't think of a way to hide that fact from users in
>> all cases.
>> >
>> > David Saff
>> >
>> > On Tue, Dec 30, 2008 at 11:18 AM, Ilja Preuß
>> > <iljapreuss@...<iljapreuss%40googlemail.com>
>> > >wrote:
>> >
>> > > Kent, I agree that it is expected behavior, technically.
>> I think you
>> > > could also make an argument that it would be better if
>> the behavior
>> > > was different.
>> > >
>> > > In my view, the behavior is in fact an artifact of an
>> implementation
>> > > detail - namely that asserts indicate failures by throwing an
>> > > exception. It could be made the case that JUnit "should" report
>> > > those failing asserts as failing asserts, not as
>> unexpected exceptions.
>> > > Basically, the current behavior masks the true test failure.
>> > >
>> > > Frankly, I have a hunch that the best solution to this problem
>> > > actually is to split the test in two, that is, to not mix
>> "expected"
>> > > and "assert" in the same test method.
>> > >
>> > > Cheers, Ilja
>> > >
>> > > 2008/12/30 kentb <kentb@... <kentb%40earthlink.net>
>> > > <kentb%
>> > 40earthlink.net>>:
>> > >
>> > > > Yosef,
>> > > >
>> > > > The behavior you describe is what I would expect to see. In the
>> > > > test,
>> > you
>> > > > declared that an ArrayIndexOutOfBounds exception would
>> be thrown.
>> > > > It
>> > was
>> > > not
>> > > > thrown, so the test fails. The error message says that
>> the "wrong"
>> > > exception
>> > > > that was thrown was an AssertionError, which is
>> generated by the
>> > > > assertTrue(false). The "expected=..." means that a test
>> can fail
>> > > > if no exception is thrown or if the wrong exception is thrown.
>> > > >
>> > > > Regards,
>> > > >
>> > > > Kent Beck
>> > > > Three Rivers Institute

>> > > > Subject: [junit] Priority of Assertion?
>> > > >
>> > > > Hi
>> > > > I use "@Test(expected = AnyClassException.class") and one
>> > > > "assertTrue(false)" together for example following code:
>> > > >
>> > > > @Test(expected = ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.class)
>> > > > public void test()
>> > > > {
>> > > > String s[] = new String[]{"1"};
>> > > > assertTrue(false);
>> > > > System.out.println(s[10]);
>> > > > }
>> > > >
>> > > > I expect to see an assertion but I see following error:
>> > > > java.lang.Exception: Unexpected exception,
>> > > > expected<java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException> but
>> > > > was<java.lang.AssertionError>..
>> > > >
>> > > > In your opinion, this test must be Assertion or Exception.
>> > > > In "JUnit" we cannot use "@Test(expected =
>> > > > AnyClassException.class") and Assertion together at the
>> same time.
>> > > > In my opinion this test must be failed for "assertion"
>> and not for
>> > > > ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
>> > > > Is this a bug in JUnit or my test is wrong and
>> shouldn't use two
>> > > > item together?
>> > > > Tanks.
